questiontext.text:
If \(z=a+i b\) is any complex number then the complex conjugate of \(z\) is denoted by \(z^*\) and is defined by \[z^*=a-i b.\](Sometimes the notation \(\bar z\) is used instead of \(z^*\) to denote the conjugate).

For example if \(z=2-3i\) then \(z^*=2+3i\).

If \(z\) is entirely real then \(z^*=z\) whereas if \(z\) is entirely imaginary then \(z^*=-z\). E.g. if \(z=17i\) then \(z^*=-17i\).

In fact the following relationships are easily obtained: \[\qquad \text{Re}(z)={z+z^*\over 2}\qquad \text{and}\qquad \text{Im}(z)={i(z^*-z)\over {2}}\]

Complex numbers are added, subtracted, multiplied and divided in much the same way as these operations are carried out for real numbers.
